citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
At the time of inspection on 03/28/2023, a male Nigerian dwarf goat kid, named 'Stumpy', born 12/25/2022, was observed
walking on it's front legs only. The hind legs ended in stumps just above the level of the hooves. The stumps were red,
with uneven damaged tissue covering the ends of the bones, and painful when manipulated. Both ears were missing
approximately the last 1/3 of the flap, and there were 1 inch in diameter scabs present covering the middle portion of the
end of the ears. The kid was thin, and the spine and pelvis lacked normal muscle and fat deposits covering the bone.
The licensee stated that she found the kid missing hooves and ends of ears when it was born, and that she had kept it in
her house and bottlefed it. She returned it to the herd with it's mother after approximately one month. The licensee stated
that she did not seek veterinary guidance because she felt the veterinarian would recommend euthanasia. Inability to
walk on the hind legs is a sign of pain, and failure to call for veterinary guidance on the lack of hooves, wounds on the
ends of the limbs, and the scabbing and missing portions of the ears are serious welfare problems. The licensee must
ensure that veterinary guidance is followed, and that the veterinarian has adequate authority to treat animal welfare
problems and ameliorate suffering.
Correct by end of day 03/29/2023.

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The male beige alpaca born in 2014, called 'Puda', was observed at the time of inspection to be squinting, and to have
alopecia and white to yellowish exudate around the left eye. The exudate was present in dried clumps from the back of
the lids to the jawline. Under the left eye was a @ 2 by 3 inch in diameter patch of bare skin under matted hair that was
reddened and flaky. There was a patch of hair loss at the left side of the lips on the muzzle. There was some hairloss
around the right eyelids. The alpaca resisted catching and holding, and jerked away from a hand on his head. The
squinting and resistance to manipulation indicate pain and discomfort. The hairloss and amount of discharge present are
indicative of a chronic welfare problem. The licensee stated that she had not noticed the problem. Accurate daily
observation of the animals and direct frequent communication with the veterinarian to obtain guidance on care and
treatment of the animal's health problem is necessary to ensure animal welfare. The licensee must make certain that all
animals are observed for health issues daily and that the veterinarian is consulted promptly about problems of animal
welfare.
Correct by the end of the day 03/29/2023.

There was an accumulation of miscellaneous boards and planting supplies in the greenhouse serving as the pig and
alpaca shelter. On the ground in the goat pen broken plastic pieces, miscellaneous metal debris, an @ 4ft section of
metal cable attached to a metal post, and multiple pieces of broken glass were lying on the ground and accessible by the
animals. These materials may be ingested or come into contact by the animals and cause digestive problems or injuries.
The licensee must ensure that facilities are maintained in good repair, and that trash and waste is disposed of properly to
ensure that it is not a hazard to the animals.
Correct end of day 03/29/2023.

The male Nigerian Dwarf goat kid that lacks hind hooves and walks on it's front legs only was kept in the herd of 18 goats,
and at the time of inspection, an adult doe was observed to butt it and knock it over. This fragile, injured animal should
not be housed with animals that can cause it discomfort and pain. The licensee must ensure that animals are housed
with compatible animals that do not cause them discomfort.
Correct by end of day 03/29/2023.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee on March 28, 2023.
